reviewText: Poor Doc Martin.....misunderstood and a victim of every prejudice and pettiness that a small town can hold.  But Martin delivers a performance that will have you laughing out loud!  And the scenery....what a beauty.Every person in the town can disappoint, be mean, be untruthful, be misleading, be out for themselves.  But the doc manages to run the gamut...too bad he does not suffer fools.This is gentle, funny, outrageous; you will recognize every person in that town....you have come across them in your life in one way or another.British television delivers again....if you are feeling a bit low, tune in to Doc Martin.My vote for best episode is Louisa having the baby.  Have plenty of tissues ready...you will be laughing so hard you will be crying.

reviewText: Doc Martin, Series 1-4, is a character-focused comedy/drama like few others.  The characters are so well constructed and executed in such a short amount of time that you'll be immersed and concerned with their every activity.The primary character is, of course, Doctor Martin Ellingham. He has just moved to the hickishly small village of Portwenn from London because of a horrible revulsion at the sight of blood. This wouldn't be a terrible problem except that he was a world-class surgeon.Now he is reduced to take a lowly position in the sticks with people who seem like hillbillies to him. Each character is presented with general hilarity or heart-cord-strumming drama.And the Doc has to interact with all of this humor and drama with what can only be considered undiagnosed Asperger's Syndrome. He is cantankerous, stand-offish, arrogant and purposefully offensive to the locals. But only because he is superior in thought and deed.You'll enjoy every last minute.In Series 1-4, you'll get:Series 1:  6 episodesSeries 2:  8 episodes + 2-episode-length Christmas specialSeries 3:  7 episodesSeries 4:  8 episodes(Episodes are roughly 45 minutes)Also note that this is the not the fully complete series -- only the complete series thus far. Series 5 will be showing later this year (2011).

reviewText: My wife and me just loved the Doc Martin series. We enjoyed this collection and were so engrossed in the Doc Martin shows that we just couldn't stop watching it.We looked forward to seeing his shows every moment we had. We even re-watch them.We were disappointed in the fact that the series ended. We wanted it to keep going on, but unfortunately it looks like there were only series 1 thru 4.Doc Martin is a wonderful and brilliant doctor as portrayed in this t.v. series. The only bad thing about the Doc is that he has no bedside manners and he is not very nice towards his patients, I guess you could say he's very mean, but he is an excellent doctor who is very devoted to his patients. He cares about his patients. Can you believe that, a doctor that actually cares about their patients. Too bad we don't have more doctors like that, except we would want them to have better bedside manners than the Doc.My wife and myself definitely would highly recommend to anyone to rent or purchase Doc Martin. We believe they will get hooked on it and would never want it to end.Bruce
summary: Doc Martin-They Don't Make Docs Like Him Anymore

reviewText: Doc Martin was a sleeper hit for us. A relative recommended it so I reluctantly bought it for my father who is a physician. After we got the subtitles working so we could understand what they were saying, immense enjoyment soon followed. My father who does not watch much television outside of sports fell in love with this cute comedy/drama. Our family's favorite show in the 90's was Seinfeld and then later we got addicted to Lost but lately we have not had anything good to watch as a family. We are not into crime shows or even medical dramas. And for my dad to be able to enjoy a show it has to be somewhat "clean" meaning no graphic sex or profanity. This was the perfect vehicle to deliver some clean fun entertainment. The characters are charming and the writing is excellent but the real star of the show is the scenery- the quaint little seaside village used for the town is simply adorable. Right on the water with plenty of beautiful green pastures. Doc Martin himself is wickedly funny. I cannot say enough about this delightful discovery. Forget Downton Abbey... this is the British show that has left us panting for more. We marathon watched the 5 available seasons (or as the Brits call them, "series") and are now eagerly awaiting the sixth season hopefully coming out soon. One unappealing character in the first season is the Doc's secretary Elaine. I guess she wasn't well received b/c she didn't make it into any further seasons thankfully. She was quite annoying. However, keep in mind she is only in the first season and then we are treated to the entry of her cousin as her replacement. She is so much more appealing. All the village's characters are loveable quirky people who play off the curmudgeon Doc Martin extremely well. I recommend just going ahead and purchasing the complete collection of seasons 1-4 instead of buying them separately b/c, for one thing, it's cheaper in the long run if you like the whole series and also b/c the individual season 1 did not have subtitles which for us was a necessity since we Southerners had difficulty understanding the thick British accents. This show is such a treat and you certainly don't have to be in the medical field to appreciate it. I highly recommend this for mature audiences- kids probably wouldn't find it funny but mature grown-ups are likely to.

reviewText: When my wife and I first started watching Doc Martin I was doubtful that it would hold my attention. After two episodes (at most) I was hooked. Martin Clunes is absolutely brilliant as the totally socially inept Doc Martin. Catherine Catz is equally compelling as Louisa, the town's schoolteacher, whose on-again-off-again romance with Doc is itself enough to keep a person anticipating the next episode. However, there's far more to it than this that makes the entire series addictive. In addition to the great acting not just by Clunes and Catz but by all the other characters, the dialogue is amazing. (The screenwriters are truly geniuses.) Moreover, each episode is full of plots and subplots, skillfully woven together to form a seamless whole. Over the course of the episodes we come to know the residents of Portwenn (the town in which the series takes place) better and better, understanding their idiosyncrasies, their ambitions, their fears, and so forth. Watching Doc Martin has been a truly rewarding experience.

reviewText: Fans of well-written, well-acted drama should not miss this tremendous comedy/ drama from across the pond.  "Doc Martin" is Dr. Martin Ellingham, a London surgeon who develops an aversion to the sight and smell of blood, forcing him to take a post as a GP in a small Cornwall village.  Each story focuses around some kind of medical challenge or puzzle, while also allowing time for the ill-mannered doctor to interact with an array of eccentric locals.  As the series progresses, viewers learn more about Martin and get a sense of why he behaves the way he does.  For all his rudeness, he's an easy character to sympathize with, even if viewers will frequently want to throttle him for being such a blockhead.The cast is tremendous from top to bottom, and the storytelling is for the most part first-rate.  The third season falters a bit (too many sub-plots that are never really resolved), but the rest are simply stellar.  With a fifth season currently in production, newcomers to the show will want to get caught up now, and this boxed set is a terrific way to start.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have seen most of the episodes of this extremely funny series and used to watch Martin Clunes in 'Men Behaving Badly,' where he was equally clever and funny.This is the story of a highly respected surgeon from a hospital in London who develops an aversion to blood.  He, therefore, cannot perform surgery anymore so becomes a GP, family physician in a village in Cornwall where his aunt (Stephanie Cole) lives.  The people of Cornwall are not hillbillies as one reviewer stated, but are an isolated people who are very attached to their villages and ways.  Cornwall is a place where artists like to gather and the beauty of the surrounding countryside is a pleasure to see.  Since I am from England, I can really appreciate the country, people, accents and scenery.  I understand the dialect and the language spoken in this series which make it much more pleasant to see.This is a program for many people to watch who have a particular sense of humour as the 'Doc.' who is an abrasive, arrogant, pompous person stands for no nonsense from anyone.  He is direct and to the point but gets himself into so many situations he cannot understand (typical of a surgeon) as he does not talk with patients, rather he talk AT patients.  I appreciate this man as I am somewhat the same, like to be direct although without the abrasiveness.  Will watch this over and over again as I loved it and all the players in it, especially Martin Clunes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: DOC MARTIN (seasons 1-4, 2004-2010, season 5, 2010-2011 sold separately, originally broadcast on UK's ITV1) is all about poor Dr. Martin Ellingham ('Doc Martin'), stuck in the mythical Cornish fishing town of Portwenn (actually Port Isaac) - one of the several things I adore about this show. Everything is shot on location in and around Port Isaac, so the town serves as an additional character. Beautiful place. Boscastle is listed as the location for season 1, but actually I know nothing about that.In case you lived in a hole with no PBS, Doc Martin gets stuck serving in the town of Portwenn after suddenly developing a severe blood phobia. I love the fact that Doc's surname, Ellingham, is an anagram of the series creator/writer, Dominic Minghella (creator/writer ofHamish MacBeth: Series 1-3 Collectionand uncle of super-cute actor Max Minghella). Especially interesting because only the Doc calls himself that - everyone else of course calls him Doc Martin. Thanks to his feisty old Aunt Ruth Ellingham (immortal Eileen Atkins), the Doc finds a job awaiting him in Cornwall when he is forced to leave his hospital.Martin Clunes, whom I also adore, did some films -Saving Grace, DOC MARTIN and DOC MARTIN AND THE LEGEND OF THE CLOUTIE (all here:Doc Martin: The Movies) in which he played a Dr. Martin 'Doc Martin' Bamford; allegedly this excellent series is claimed to have been inspired by those films, but the character is completely different. Doc Martin has an acid tongue, a quiet, dangerous growl, an autistic incomprehension of the humans around him, and an evil bedside manner. The goofy, cheerful folks of Port Wen don't really care - they know all about Doc, and don't even try to steer clear of him.This is a naturally funny 'dramedy'-style series, one of those precious breaths of fresh British (Cornish!) air, that I just love and don't ever see often enough. The acting is sharp and spot-on; the humor is 1st rate; the series has adult themes but in my opinion is a fine family series to own. All I can do to conclude this is outline a few of my personal favorite episodes:-"Always On My Mind": Doc Martin and his auntie struggle with a man, Phil Pratt (the great Roger Lloyd-Pack ofHarry Potter and the Goblet of Fire) who loses his wife and blames Doc; a sort of comic tragedy exposes a vital fact about this man at the end. This has to be one of the funniest television episodes of anything I have ever seen!Sorry, folks, can't find the titles from here forward, you'll see them if you buy the collection!-Doc deals with a young war veteran who copes with his PTS by having a giant imaginary rabbit as a friend.-Doc deals with two brothers and their dangerously crazy father.-Doc comes grievously close to declaring his love for sexy school marm Louisa (stunningly gorgeous Caroline Catz). Actually, Doc doesn't seem to be absolutely certain what love really is.-Early in season one, Doc deals with the cancer diagnosis of an old hippy neighbor (Jeff Rawle again of HARRY POTTER AND THE GOBLET OF FIRE) and has to return to his old stomping grounds only to hear people prattling about why he left.
summary: One of the best TV shows ever produced

reviewText: Me mum told me she'd been catching this on PBS and liked it a lot. I told my wife and we started streaming it on Netflix. We're hooked in the worst way. Some times we'll watch as many as 4 episodes back to back.Here's the scoop. This is a fish out of water tale. Dr. Martin Ellingham is a hot shot surgeon in London. The preassures of the job finally hit him in an unexpected way. It causes him to contract a fear of blood, the sight of which makes him violently ill. As a result he is forced to pack his bags and take a job as a G.P. in Portwenn, Cornwall, where he finds himself at odds with an eccentric bunch of locals who drive him mad. But Portwenn is also home to a lovely school teacher. Though she is quite his opposite, he takes a shine to her. Can he find true love?This is a hoot. Martin Clunes creates a great character with the doctor. He absolutely must wear a suit and tie each day though there is little need to. He must have his espresso each morning and he lacks even the most basic interactive skills. But he's an incredible doctor which is why the local school marm fancies him as much as he does her. She's a doll. She's pretty without being glamorous and she has a nice way about her. There are some other locals that are also painted well, such as the doctor's aunt who often manages to let him know when he's screwing up.It's generally written very well. One of the drawbacks of watching episodes back to back is you see when the writers need to force a plot point and put a character...out of character. And he runs into too many exotic maladies for such a tiny hamlet. But these instances do little to hurt the overall enjoyment. I also like the main musical theme, which is very cool and is repeated in different arrangements throughout the episodes. It's fun picking it out during the various scenes.The setting of Portwenn is idyllic. It is a trully lovely place and lends itself effortlessly to the camera. You want to be there.This is just a solid, fun effort all the way around. It's very British and handles itself in a way only the British can. If you at all like this sort of thing this will run right into your veins.

reviewText: Anyone appreciative of the English good humor/pathos would be well advised to buy this series at your earliest convenience.  There's no blood and gore scenes, just the proverbial English nosiness-types set in a seaside village.  The interactions between these personalities/exchanges could well be used to imprint caring, sensitive souls into lessons learned of love for our fellow creatures.  Doc Martin's interpretation covers an old soul in a newy acquired set of circumstances that are both hilarious, yet touching.  His gruff manner hides a great heart.  Keep up the good works, Doc.
summary: Doctor Martin Ellingham (Doc Martin); what a "trip"
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first saw the Doc Martin show on my local PBS station, where it often still plays, and became totally caught up in him and his little world.  Doc Martin is a British comedy with all that en tales: a dry, subtle type of comedy; 1st class production values and an excellent cast of supporting "quirky characters."  Doc Martin is the only local medical practitioner in a small coastal community in the Cornwall (?) area of southern England.  He was once an important surgeon, living and working in London, until he developed a phobia regarding fear of the sight of blood, thus causing him to take up what he sees as this lesser position.  While a very good doctor, he's tactless, doesn't have ANY bedside manner or, in general, any "people skills" and therefore is usually rather stand-offish with patients and other village folk, which causes him to become trapped in situations whose source was some type of misunderstanding or  the dislike of him, including his receptionist and a potential love-interest.This set is the first four seasons of the show, 30 episodes, with subtitles.  The comedy generally is of a situational variety and episodes are all "PG" in nature for family viewing.
summary: Doc Martin is an acquired taste but worth the effort
Title: N/A

reviewText: My wife and I became hooked on Doc Martin when we saw on PBS part of the initial movie that inspired the series followed by a few series episodes. Martin Clunes is marvelous at portraying the Doc who is a major grump with no social skills or beside manner, yet is super competent and totally dedicated to delivering the best health care to the host community. It is a joy to watch him interact with the quirky residents of small Portwenn, a fishing village dramatically carved into the coast line of Cornwall, UK.The Doc's romantic interest Louisa, the headmistress of the local elementary school, is played by the lovely Catherine Catz, who's personality is the complete opposite to the Doc's.  Watch the sparks fly as the closer they get, the more dysfunctional the relationship becomes. The whole thing is great fun, so let yourself become one the Doc's addicts where the only cure is to watch all 5 series.

reviewText: Why so funny? A surgeon is mentally and physically indisposed at the sight of blood. You will laugh at quirky townsfolk in this serene, beautiful little seaside Cornwall town of Portwenn. Laughter happens with most scenes through 30 episodes of this 9 DVD collection. Often I raise eyebrows to the Mrs (we watched together), she picks up a corner of her mouth, and again we're belly laughing.We thoroughly enjoyed all stories and weird but lovable characters in this small fishing berg. Doc Martin (Martin Clunes-'Dirty Tricks' 'Demob' 'Lorna Doone') is stern, grumpy, all-business, rude, and shows a heartless bedside manner, adding to the hilarity--as he fails to see any of the villagers' joy and friendliness. The medical conditions he addresses are often as hilarious as the symptom complainants. Mix in romances, mysteries, and even some touching moments. Some of the best British Comedy/Drama ever produced. A photogenic setting backdrop to LOL hilarious activity in a doctor's wee-town life.About the only thing that compares to this collection of fun-but-wierd characters is...well, Portwenn is a British Mayberry R.F.D. Cornwall corny (filmed in Port Isaac, beautiful quaint fishing port.) Eccentric locals include Aunt Joan (Stephanie Cole-'A Bit of a Do' 'Housewife,49' 'Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day') slightly sane; teacher Louisa (Caroline Cutz-'The Guilty' 'The Vice') worthy of romance; surgery receptionist Pauline (Katherine Parkinson) is outrageously funny wanting a man; Large Jr., Al (Joe Absolom) son of Bert Large (Ian McNeice-'Oliver Twist' 'Rome')plumber turned chef (don't order soup). That's just the short-list of a crazy cast that keeps a tapestry of sub-plots moving fast.A family series, which does have a series 4 'graphic medical scene' warning due to numerous accidents involving some blood for Doc Martin to gag or spew from. This surgeon's blood phobia is part of the absurd humor. If you love English seaside village views and homespun humor, this will do...and make you beg for more. Episodes carry over to the next and all with...SUBTITLES.This collection is the economical purchase plan for this series. You will be glad you own. Very re-watchable.
summary: BELLY LAUGHING HIT BRITISH COMEDY SERIES

reviewText: Dr. Martin Ellingham is one of the most fascinating characters in all of TV drama.  Captivatingly played by Martin Clunes, he is a skilled and dedicated doctor in a Cornish fishing village, honest, courageous, and tenacious when treating  patients in distress. In every important way, he is a supremely moral man.  But he does not suffer fools kindly.He is a good man, but not a nice man. He is, in fact, damned rude.He is actually a complex psychological study--the unwanted child of self-absorbed parents ("I was locked under the stairs many times as a child and it didnt' affect me"), who had to quit surgery because of a blood-phobia. He might--or might not--have Asperger Syndrome. But he exemplifies a valuable point: "nice" is the most overrated of virtues.  The world is full of nice people who are not worth a cow pie in the road.  Or, worse, on whom you had better never turn your back.  I will take the Ellinghams, who are strong, and whose strength makes them worthy of our trust.As usual in these British ensemble dramas, there is a swirl of finely-played secondary characters, the main one being Louisa Glasson, Martin's maybe-girlfriend who has the insight to see his quality and the fortitude to endure his many clueless slights."Strong" is a higher virtue than "nice."  This series illustrates that in a hundred ways, with humanity and humor.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Doc Martin is the bench mark against which medical dramas should be measured.  Doc Martin is a dysfunctional but dedicate MD in a village of very unique personalities.
summary: Doc Martin beats "House" at very turn.

reviewText: The first two seasons are most of what the other reviewers say they are, with a charming plot line and wonderfully quirky characters you can't help but love and care about. Four stars for the (understandable) lack of a complete narrative arc.Then the original writer (Minghella?) is replaced by a series of vastly inferior writers and the plot line is replaced with a series of decreasingly compelling and decreasingly funny cliches. The final-episode deus ex machina only makes the growing fecklessness of the last two seasons the more dispiriting.Try to watch season 3 before you buy it.

reviewText: If you're a fan of British comedies and dramas, this series is for you. It is rich in caracter devlopment and shot on location in a beautiful Cornwall village. reviewText: I wish that American television had shows like this.  It really reminds me of a cross between the quirkiness of Northern Exposure with the abrupt nature of Hugh Laurie's character in the series "House". Martin Clunes is brilliant by staying in character while allowing his emotional vulnerabilities to show through at key moments.  In addition, the writing crew really developed the rest of the cast and allows them to play strong supporting roles as friends and key members of the community.  My entire family loves that the series continues as a "day in the life" sort of experience that continues on rather than having episodes with completely separate plots.Love It! Love It! Love It!

reviewText: A surgeon develops a phobia about blood and moves from London to be the village doctor in Port Wen.  This is the opening premise. Doc Martin still has the surgeon's bedside manner (none) . Despite his pompous demeanor and phobia, he definately cares about his patients and the learn to cope with his mannerisms.  In the process, we have a subtle but enjoyable four seasons of British Humor.

reviewText: The premise of this series is a successful London surgeon is suddenly allergic to blood and goes to the village of Port Wenn to become the local GP.  His bedside manor is much like the lunchtime manor of a hungry alligator -- he is nasty to everyone in his blunt to-the-point way. He has many opportunities with local dogs, to make points, but fails miserably -- enough for us to join the jeering villagers.  His only saving grace is his medical ability to  save lives and sniff out odd disease, howver, in his overbearing way, the may trample on everyone although he may be partially right. For example, he villafies the village water supply when in fact one of the local characters in selling "spring water" from a contaminated sheep field.Doc's total lack of bedside manner is made up by a lovely cast higlighting the delightful village characters. Some scenes such as the birth of his "girlfriend's" baby via cellphone and microphone is followed by the whole village. We love the village and don't care much for the Doc.  When we first watched this, we were uncertain if we would watch the next one.In sum Doc is a man of few words, which probably shouldn't have been spoken anyway.  However, in the end we are sorry gthere were only four seasons.  We really like the locals and the locale.
summary: The nasty doc and the quait villagers
Title: N/A

reviewText: As I'd already been watching Doc Martin on MPBN tv, I knew what I'd be getting when I sent for Series 1-4. There was no possibility of disappointment. Words rather fail me when it comes to describing these episodes. The landscape and harbor in Cornwall add so much to the stories. Port Wenn (Port Isaac, actually), captures my imagination almost as much as Martin Clunes' demeanor as the painfully blunt, unconsciously rude Doc Martin who offends everyone he deals with in any way. I have to say he is unconsciously rude, as truly he has no clue what effect his dismissive behavior has on others. Underneath, he does care about his patients and wants them healthy. One look at the way his father and mother treat him during a disagreeable visit to Port Wenn, and to a great degree you can realize much of why Martin is the way he is. More insight comes in very brief intervals, in the form of remarks by Martin's Aunt Joan.  Oh, this series is wonderful. Give it a look, if you haven't already.
summary: Doc Martin, Series 1-4, Never, Ever Disappoints.

reviewText: "Doc Martin" is one of the funniest, most intelligent, and most poignant shows on television.The DVD set is merely adequate. There are also no special features, though that's more of a "nice to have" item than the episode guide, whose lack is a significant inconvenience. As with many DVD sets, the DVD cases are cheap and flimsy.Five stars for the show, averaged with three stars for the DVD set, gives an overall rating of four stars.
summary: Superb TV show, minimal DVD set

reviewText: If you are new to Doc martin or want to share it with someone, It's worth it to get the 1-4 package (on sale if you can). I fully enjoyed this series and look forward to the next season. It is currently running on PBS and series 6 will be shooting in 2013, this will be the last year for this show. I have not seen series 5 yet but from what i have read, series 1-4 are the best ones.The directing and producing is top notch and care is given to each episode. We really appreciate that!Martin Clunes has wonderful chemistry with the cast in the wonderful setting of Port Issac and i believe actress Caroline Catz has a house there now too. I'm a coasty myself and absolutely love the setting.I am a fan of "All Creatures Great and Small" and this show reminds me of that quality. It has a great cast, beautiful scenery and hilarious small town living.

reviewText: Very rarely when watching a show on Netflix (where Seasons 1-4 are currently available) do I stop the download and repeat a scene.  I do this frequently with Doc Martin.  Martin Clunes is a very subtle actor, and his scenes with Stephanie Cole (Aunt Joan) and Caroline Catz (Louisa) are worth repeating.The show grows on you--the writing is extraordinary and the characters are allowed to grow and change.  I wouldn't say that every plot is completely believable and occasionaly the dottering senior citizen is turned into an element of humor (a British speciality), but overall this is one of the best TV series of all time.
summary: One of the All Time Best Series

reviewText: As an American who has stopped watching most all of the abysmal fare on 180 cable stations and mindless films in the theaters (Frasier, Seinfeld, and the Science channel  on TV, and "About a Boy" some years ago in the theaters being the exceptions that prove the rule that there is so little to waste time watching), but who is now constantly seeking Netflix streaming shows seeking top notch writing acting,I came across Doc Martin quite by accident. I have never been inclined to watch medical shows (like Grey's Anatomy and the like), but my sister, who is a doctor mentioned several times that she had been wathcing "Doc Martin" on Netflix, so in desperation one night I turned it on thinking I wouldn't watch for more than a few minutes before looking for something else. The rest is history, because I became instantly hooked,watching the first four seasons in less than a week; and then just as I became addicted to the most charming show I've ever watched in a lifetime, I came to the end of the 31st episode only to see that Netflix ended it there. Now as a result I am suffering withdrawal symptoms, and immeiately ordered season 5 despite its inordinate costs compared to the unlimited streaming I get on Netflix for $8 a month. Perhaps part of my addiction is due to my Nostalgia for England, where I went to school in Newbury, Berkshire from age 6-12, and even more to Cornwall which I've never seen but nevertheless written novels about. In any case, I dread the thought that the series might end with 6. Can anyone put my mind to rest?

reviewText: Martin Clunes was made for this role.  He was a practicing surgeon in London who had to leave his position because he developed a phobia against blood.  He then became the GP in the small village of Portwenn.  The story evolves around the many characters he meets when he opens his practice and the lack of interpersonal relationshilps he has with his patients.  He is blunt,rude and highly confident.  He meets his love interest, Louisa, aboard the plane heading into Portwenn. He adores his aunt Joan, respects his aunt Ruth, does not like his parents. Louisa ont he other hand has a dad who is a gambler and a thief and a mother who loves Portugal. You'll meet PC Mylow and PC Joe Penhale and the loveable Bert Large and his son Al. You'll meet Doc's first kooky eccentric receptionist, Elaine, and her cousin Pauline who replaces her after Elaine leaves (with her boyfriend Greg) for Spain. Doc now has a third new receptionist, Morwenna. You will also meet the chemist, Sally Tishell, who has an attraction for Doc Martin even though she is married to Clive Tishell who works for an oil rig at sea and isn’t home very often. Fantastic Entertainment....simply hilarious.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love, love, love this series. Please, I want more! the Doc Martin character is IMPOSSIBLE, yet you can't hate him. You root for him and keep hoping he  will turn into a bit more of a HUMAN.  He's hilarious and never tries to be even funny.  The plots are quirky to say the least.  The Cornwall setting of Port Isaac, a fishing village called Port Wenn in the series,will having you wanting to book airline tickets to the UK and then wanting to rent a car and head for Cornwall.  Wish I could.....not anytime soon.A special treat is the "can't live with him, can't live without him","am drawn to him but he annoys the hell out of me" relationship that the Louisa character has with Doc Martin.  Just don't miss this series. I was totally addicted and watched it every day till I got through the end of Series 4. I want Series 5!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was living in Britain when 'Doc Martin' began on ITV1 and I was always missing the new episodes but then ITV3 (I'm speaking about British channels here, if you'll forgive me) began airing repeats and I finally got to watch them and I was instantly hooked. I treated myself to the series 1-4 boxset and I watched them all over the course of 2 days and now I cannot wait for the 5th series. I just moved to America and brought all my "stuffy" British comedy which the American population "doesn't get" (I jest. My American wife and my in-laws find it all hilarious....well...mostly all of it. lol) and Doc Martin is the show i'm currently bombarding them with.As a Briton. I'm naturally biased for all of the good stuff that's produced there and some of you may be on the fence about viewing this but we do all speak the same language (after a fashion) and I promise you will enjoy the brilliant scripting and acting of this show and it's stars. It's really Top notch!On a side note, the character of Doc Martin was co-created by Craig Ferguson (Yes, the very same 'Late Late Show' host) for a wonderful 2000 film which he also starred in called 'Saving Grace' Martin Clunes also played the Doc in this movie and it was also filmed in Port Isaac but as you'll notice if you watch that movie and this series that the character was the polar opposite of the Doc Martin we know today and (with no disrespect to Ferguson) his character is much better today. His grumpiness and inability to involve himself with the locals makes him a more like-able person, if that makes any sense, than the one he portrayed in 'Saving Grace' A tribute to Clunes' acting, no less.So all in all. A terrific series and I'm looking forward to the 5th series that's going to be aired later this year.
summary: Doc Martin is One of ITV's Best....

reviewText: I have watched several of the series on PBS and bought series 5 recently. Thus I got this set which is an excellent buy for the money. It is also time well spent viewing. The beauty of Cornwall cannot be surpassed. The locals are well portrayed and Doc Martin played by Martin Clunes is a study in the development of a gruff natured person turning over a new perspective in being more cognizent of others' emotional needs. He relys too much on logic like Mr. Spock in Star Trek but even more so. I loved it and also the love story between Martin and Louisa which  is moving and shows the real  development of human feelings and love. When a child is conceived they finally realize the need for each other but there are still difficulties ahead. Good story line and excellent acting and the beautiful background scenery make it well worth viewing time and time again.
summary: Bought after seeing Doc Martin series 5
